stem: A 72-year-old client with pre-existing CKD (Stage 2) underwent a CT Angiogram with contrast 48 hours ago. Based on the documentation in the Serial Nephrology & Procedural Log, which finding is the most definitive indicator of Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN)?

options.text: The increase in Serum Creatinine of > 25% from baseline within 48 hours
The high volume of contrast used (150 mL)
The patient's refusal of oral hydration

rationale.correct: The definitive clinical definition of **Contrast-Induced Nephropathy (CIN) (a1)** is an absolute increase in serum creatinine of at least 0.5 mg/dL or a **relative increase of > 25%** from the baseline within 48–72 hours of contrast exposure. Here, the creatinine doubled from 1.2 to 2.4, confirming AKI directly caused by the contrast media. The lack of hydration post-procedure greatly increased the toxicity of the contrast in the renal tubules.
clinicalPearls: CIN is a form of Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN) caused by direct cellular toxicity and vasoconstriction.
Prevention: IV Normal Saline or Sodium Bicarbonate before AND after the procedure.
Creatinine usually peaks 3–5 days post-contrast and then returns to baseline in 7–10 days.
Withhold Metformin for 48 hours after contrast to prevent lactic acidosis if CIN occurs.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Edema is a *symptom* of fluid retention due to kidney failure, but it is not specific to contrast. The **creatinine trend** is the only way to mathematically confirm CIN.

exhibits.title: Procedural Note
exhibits.content:
Procedure: CT Angiogram of Chest/Abdomen.
Contrast: 150 mL High-Osmolar IV Contrast given.
Hydration: 500 mL NS given pre-procedure. Post-procedure orders for 100 mL/hr NS not followed due to 'patient refusal to drink.'

exhibits.title: Nursing Observations
exhibits.content: Current: Client has developed 2+ pitting edema in ankles. Urine is dark and concentrated; total output 350 mL in last 24 hours. No reports of flank pain or dysuria.
